awd_titl_txt: Step Up to Physical Science and Engineering
awd_abstract_narration:
This National Science Foundation (NSF) Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (S-STEM) project at Randolph College in Lynchburg, Virginia will provide scholarships for talented, low-income students pursuing bachelor's degrees with a major in a physical science, engineering, or mathematics. In addition to scholarships, the program will provide academic support to increase persistence and degree completion. Project efforts will include an intensive summer transition program; a seminar series through the four years of college; enhanced tutoring services in a living-learning community; peer, faculty, and industry mentoring program; and enhanced access to internships and research opportunities. The project will also conduct research to help determine the most effective way to utilize mentors from industry in helping to support student degree completion. Scholarships and support for academically strong low-income students, who may not otherwise be able to afford college, will help to produce a well-trained workforce that will contribute to the economic vitality of Virginia and the nation.

This project will advance understanding of the role of living-learning communities, research participation and use of mentors from industry to increase retention and degree attainment in STEM majors. Mentoring will be a particular subject of study. While the value of mentoring is well accepted, a majority of prior work in this area focuses on peer or faculty mentors. The project at Randolph College will study mentoring of undergraduates by industry professionals. The study will attempt to assess factors impacting students' potential for mentoring and will develop effective models for structuring the mentoring experience with mentors from industry. The findings that emerge from the program will be disseminated widely to the STEM education community and will help to increase understanding of the attributes and practices of successful student scholarship and support programs.

por.por_cntn:
Randolph College is a nationally recognized, small, private liberal arts college in Lynchburg, Virginia. Randolph has a history of educating successful scientists and engineers, and the SUPER Program has helped to provide access to an excellent education and to more resources, for a larger and more diverse group of students.

Step-Up to Physical Science and Engineering at Randolph (SUPER) is a program that educates America?s future scientists and engineers. SUPER has been funded through the NSF S-STEM Program under grant number DUE-1564970. As well as helping to fund the program which recruits 24 students each year, the S-STEM grant funds scholarships for a subset of these students, which ended up being 54 students in four cohorts through the life of the grant, 29 of which have graduated so far. Through the SUPER Program, we have developed support services which help make sure the student is doing everything they can to be a successful scientist. Outcomes include increased retention in STEM, increased numbers of STEM majors, and a larger number of STEM graduates entering the workforce.

This is the second grant we have received from the S-STEM program, with the first allowing us to develop the initial SUPER Program. This project allowed us to enhance the components of the program that have worked and modify those that did not. Initially we developed five components which have become models for other students and programs at the college and at other colleges, and through this new project we developed new components of the students? experience. We developed a College Transition (Bridge) Program for new students, a system of enhanced support services, a Living-Learning Community, an Industry Mentor Program, a four-year career plan, and specialized academic seminars for each year. In addition, we place a significant emphasis on research and internship experiences.

We have targeted under-represented groups in the physical sciences and have increased the number of applicants to the college interested in science, have increased retention, have increased the number of majors in the sciences, and have seen great success upon graduation.

While the objective of this program was to recruit 36 S-STEM scholars in two cohorts, we have been able to recruit 54 S-STEM scholars in four cohorts, and a total of 97 SUPER scholars during that time. Of these, 29 S-STEM scholars have graduated, part of the total 43 SUPER scholars that have graduated so far, noting that only three of the four cohorts have reached graduation. The gender and ethnic diversity of the SUPER science scholars represents that of the College as a whole. Over the six years of this project, we have continued to grow the STEM majors at a higher rate than other majors at the college, or in pandemic years when enrollments struggled, STEM did not drop as quickly as other fields. The hallmark of this program is that retention of SUPER students each year has been significantly greater than the college as a whole. Our retention of traditionally under-represented minority groups has been particularly excellent, with even higher retention of these groups than SUPER as a whole. We believe that the cohort model, the sense of belonging, and the purposeful identity as a ?scientist? from recruiting through college helps students feel like they are part of something important and helps to keep them focused on being a scientist or engineer through graduation.

All graduates from the SUPER Program are employed or are in graduate school. 95% of the graduates from the two cohorts that have graduated are doing something related to their STEM degree.

 


Last Modified: 10/27/2023
Modified by: Peter A Sheldon
